quiz.title: Unit 9: Market Failure & Public Policy (Quiz 1)
quiz.subtitle: AP Microeconomics — Externalities, Social vs. Private Outcomes
quiz.subject: AP Microeconomics
quiz.topic: Externalities, Market Efficiency, Socially Optimal Quantity, Welfare Analysis

questions.question: A negative externality exists when
options: a third party bears a cost from a market transaction they are not involved in
a producer receives a benefit they did not pay for
the social cost of production is less than the private cost
the government intervenes to correct a market failure
questions.explanation: A negative externality occurs when a transaction imposes an uncompensated cost on a third party (e.g., pollution).

questions.question: In the presence of a negative externality, the market equilibrium quantity is _________ the socially optimal quantity.
questions.explanation: With a negative externality, the private market produces too much because firms do not account for external costs. Market quantity > socially optimal quantity.

questions.question: A positive externality exists when
options: a third party receives a benefit from a market transaction they are not involved in
a consumer pays less than the social value of a good
the private benefit of consumption is greater than the social benefit
questions.explanation: A positive externality occurs when a transaction generates an uncompensated benefit for a third party (e.g., education, vaccinations).

questions.question: In the presence of a positive externality, the market equilibrium quantity is _________ the socially optimal quantity.
questions.explanation: With a positive externality, the private market produces too little because consumers/firms do not account for external benefits. Market quantity < socially optimal quantity.

questions.question: If the marginal social cost (MSC) of producing a good exceeds its marginal private cost (MPC), there is a
questions.explanation: MSC > MPC means external costs exist, indicating a negative externality in production.

questions.question: If the marginal social benefit (MSB) of consuming a good exceeds its marginal private benefit (MPB), there is a
questions.explanation: MSB > MPB means external benefits exist, indicating a positive externality in consumption.

questions.question: To correct a negative externality, the government can impose a per‑unit tax equal to the
questions.explanation: A Pigovian tax set equal to the marginal external cost (MEC) internalizes the externality, shifting the supply curve up to reflect MSC and leading to the socially optimal quantity.

questions.question: To correct a positive externality, the government can provide a per‑unit subsidy equal to the
questions.explanation: A subsidy equal to the marginal external benefit (MEB) internalizes the externality, shifting the demand curve up to reflect MSB and leading to the socially optimal quantity.

questions.question: The deadweight loss from a negative externality is the area
options: between the demand and supply curves from the market quantity to the social optimum
between the MSC and MPC curves from the social optimum to the market quantity
between the MSB and MPB curves from the market quantity to the social optimum
of the triangle between MSC and MSB at the market equilibrium
questions.explanation: For a negative externality, deadweight loss is the area between the MSC and MPC (or MSB, if demand reflects MPB) from the social optimum to the market quantity, representing the welfare loss from overproduction.

questions.question: Which of the following is an example of a good that generates a positive externality?
questions.explanation: Vaccinations provide external benefits (herd immunity) to third parties who are not directly involved in the transaction.

scoreMessages.90: Mastery of positive/negative externalities, social vs. private outcomes, corrective taxes/subsidies, and deadweight loss.
scoreMessages.70: Solid grasp; review how externalities shift MSC/MSB, identifying socially optimal quantity, and policy remedies.
scoreMessages.50: Needs practice distinguishing positive from negative externalities, comparing market and optimal quantities, and understanding Pigovian corrections.
scoreMessages.0: Focus on externality definitions (third‑party costs/benefits), market over‑ or under‑production, MSC vs. MPC, MSB vs. MPB, and tax/subsidy solutions.
